SENT.plain: In 1961, the senior author reported 11 members of one family with infantile cortical hyperostosis
Since then, 10 new cases have occurred in this family resulting in a total of 21 cases
The incidence of infantile cortical hyperostosis in this family is as common today as it was two generations ago, and there has been no diminution in the incidence
Several patients with minimal or no clinical symptoms would have gone unrecognized had it not been for the family history of the disorder
On the basis of this study, infantile cortical hyperostosis is inherited as an autosomal dominant with variable penetrance
